div1.p: Tate finds fault with Howard's play about yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Paul L. Tate, [1954]

p.del: so here is my reply to what you asked:

div1.p:
The impression the play Yellow Jack, by Sidney Howard, was if
as I were witnessing a caricarture: people bearing familiar
names and others with strange names going through actions of
which I seemed to be slightly familiar, yet I was unable to
connect it with any people I had known in Cuba, where most of
the events in the play were supposed to have transpired.

When I heard that it was to be presented on T.V. I procured a
book of the play and read it carefully. In it are the fundda-
mentals of the scientific facts of the Cuban and African ex-
periments, but to term such a drama “historical” is scarcely
justified.

Of course, Sidney Howard as a playwright had to make it inter-
esting and amusing to an audience, but to do so by twisting
the characters and convictions of real men out of all semblance
to themselves was an outrage.

I never met Moran, (the sole volunteer I did not know personally)
but I feel sure that he was never like the O'Hara of the drama
any more than Kissinger, Jernejan and Folk resembled the Brin-
kerhof, McClelland and Burch depicted in the play.

Why take Dean and have him talk of veneral disease, when, as a
calvaryman, being kicked on the knee by a horse, which as the
truth would have sufficed.

The manner of talk of these men is not only a reflection on the
men of the Hospital Corps, but on all enlisted men of the Army.
He puts them in the class of Cockney English soldiers made
famous by Rudyard Kipling. But Sidney Howard is no Kipling, so
he twists the real facts around just to make these preposterous
and would-be funny conversations possible.

As Howard, himself, wrote Gust Lambert, (the real nurse) “He had
to make the nurse a female, as an audience would not like an
all-man play.”

Doctor Gorgas had a female nurse in the virus experiments in
Havana, Cuba, and they lost 4 out of 10 cases. If Dr. Ames or
Lambert alone had been there they would have lost none. If it
had not been for Lambert, with his great, but gentle strength
and psychology, crude though it was, there would have been, per-
haps no successful finish to an experiment for Howard to make
a play about.

But I suppose it all seems fine to the audience. Sidney Howard
is one of those playwrights who must have humor even in tragedy.
But he wants too much comedy, (not humor) at the expense of of
sober, diligent, brave men who were not humorous at all. It was
deliberate, for he states in his foreword: “That it may well give
offence to those characters in the play who are still alive. -
. . and I did not attempt to protray them as they are.”

A great playwright could have made use of the men and material
(3)
in these experiments and produced a noble and interesting
drama without attempting to make buffons out of courageous men.
But, unfortunately, Mr. Howard is not a great playwright, so
he failed in producing an “Historical Drama.”

So, that is my humble opinion of the play that you asked for.
I, of course, know nothing of the African Experiments except what
I have read in the Rockeffeller Foundation bullitins, but I
guess the characters were as twisted as much as in the Cuban
affair.
